revision.comment: http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[File:Franco Hungarian Treaty of Alliance 1529.jpg|thumb|300px|Franco-Hungarian Treaty of alliance, 1529.]] {{Foreign alliances of France}} A '''Franco-Hungarian alliance''' was formed in October 1528 between [[Francis I of France]] and [[John Zápolya]], king of [[Hungary]].<ref name="Arnold">[https://books.google.com/books?id=VNAMjuMw_5kC&pg=PA537 ''The companion to British history'' Charles Arnold-Baker p.537]</ref>
==Background== France had already been looking for allies in [[Central Europe]]. His ambassador, [[Antonio Rincon]], was employed on several missions to [[Poland]] and [[Hungary]] between 1522 and 1525. At that time, following the 1522 [[Battle of Bicocca]], Francis was attempting to ally with King [[Sigismund I the Old]] of Poland.<ref name="Setton312"/>
In 1524, a [[Franco-Polish alliance]] was signed between Francis and Sigismund,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=N883AAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA309 ''The Cambridge History of Poland'' by Oskar Halecki p.309]</ref> but the agreement fell through when Francis was vanquished by [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]] at the [[Battle of Pavia]] in 1525.<ref name="Setton312">[https://books.google.com/books?id=EgQNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA312 ''The Papacy and the Levant (1204–1571)'' by Kenneth M. Setton p.312]</ref>
==Alliance with Hungary== From 1526, Francis I again started to look for allies in [[Central Europe]], this time turning his attention to [[Hungary]].<ref name="Setton312"/> In 1528, [[John Zápolya]] was in a very vulnerable position, since he had been defeated by [[Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand of Austria]], his rival claimant to the throne of Hungary, at the [[Battle of Tokay]] in August 1527.<ref name="Arnold"/> In addition to the French alliance, Zapolya also chose to become a vassal to the [[Ottoman Empire]] in February 1528, through the negotiations of [[Jerome Laski]].<ref name="Arnold"/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=EgQNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA314 ''The Papacy and the Levant (1204–1571)'' by Kenneth M. Setton p.314]</ref> Rincon went to Istanbul to bring the document.<ref>Garnier, p.16</ref> That triggered the development of relations between France and the Ottoman Empire.<ref name="Arnold"/>
The treaty was signed in France at [[Fontainebleau]] and [[Paris]] on 23 and 28 October 1528.<ref name="Setton322">[https://books.google.com/books?id=EgQNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA322 ''The Papacy and the Levant (1204–1571)'' by Kenneth M. Setton p.322]</ref> It was then ratified by Zapolya at [[Buda]] on 1 September 1529.<ref name="Setton322"/> Through the treaty Francis promised to help Zapolya financially and through other means. In exchange, Zapolya agree to continue the fight against [[Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand of Austria]] and to provide Hungarian troops to Francis in Italy.<ref name="Setton322"/>
In the [[Little War in Hungary]], France fought side by side with Zápolya and [[Suleiman the Magnificent]] against the Habsburg. A French artillery unit was dispatched to the war in Hungary in 1543–1544 and attached to the [[Ottoman Army]].<ref name="books.google.com">''The Ottoman Empire and early modern Europe'' by Daniel Goffman, p.111 [https://books.google.com/books?id=3uJzjatjTL4C&pg=PA111]</ref><ref name="Mx7jSZjIC p.38">[https://books.google.com/books?id=epaMx7jSZjIC&pg=PA38 ''Firearms of the Islamic world'', p.38]</ref><ref name="AuJvd2Tyt8C p.328">[https://books.google.com/books?id=4AuJvd2Tyt8C&pg=PA328 ''The Cambridge History of Islam'', p.328]</ref>
==See also== *[[Foreign alliances of France]] *[[Franco-Ottoman alliance]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Garnier, Edith ''L'Alliance Impie'' Editions du Felin, 2008, Paris ISBN 978-2-86645-678-8 [http://www.neopodia.mobi/20090519-histoire-renaissance-alliance-impie-francois-1er-ier-ottoman-soliman-suleyman-charles-quint-forces-en-presence Interview] {{Treaties of Hungary}}
